Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: (ST2) Integrating synthetic genetic regulatory networks into soft materials to orchestrate new forms of mechanical responsiveness
Award.AbstractNarration: Non-technical Description:<br/>This proposal aims to develop an adhesive (sticky) gel in which a chemical reaction senses mechanical force applied to the gel and, in response, alter the adhesive layer of a material to make it easier to peel or remove from the surface onto which it is bonded. One goal of developing this new method is to create a new means of easily removing adhesives on delicate tissues, such as those used for bandages, without damaging the material the adhesive is stuck to, such as skin. Inspired by discussions at the NSF-sponsored Square Table-2 meeting about how the development of materials might be advanced by incorporating ideas from synthetic biology, this project brings together two disparate fields, the study of adhesives and synthetic biology, to advance and directly improve our capabilities to create and understand medical adhesives. This project provides multi-disciplinary training for 2 graduate students and 4 undergraduate students and integrates new findings generated during the research into core and elective chemical and biomolecular engineering courses. Short courses at professional societies and to art students presented by the principal investigators about this research are designed to foment interest in these approaches to material design outside the science and engineering communities. <br/><br/>Technical Description:<br/>This project investigates how embedded molecular force sensors in hydrogels can be employed to modulate adhesion. The strategy employed by the team involves developing molecular force sensors that change conformation and expose a specific chemical domain when a predetermined amount of compression is applied to the hydrogel. The exposed domain can then interact with mobile chemical elements (such as enzymes or nucleic acid complexes) to initiate a downstream chemical cascade that leads to debonding, and ultimately to delamination. The research combines materials design, photopatterning, biomolecular conjugation, and characterization in order to obtain a new form of mechanical responsiveness and to gain a better understanding of the mechanisms behind hydrogel adhesion. Moreover, this work lays the groundwork for a new class of biomaterials in which arbitrary and complex stimuli and arbitrary and complex responses are orchestrated by molecular sensors and actuators and molecular circuits embedded within the biomaterial itself. <br/><br/>This Division of Materials Research (DMR) grant supports research to integrate synthetic genetic regulatory networks into soft materials to orchestrate new forms of mechanical responsiveness managed by the Condensed Matter Physics (CMP) Program in DMR of the Mathematical and Physical Sciences (MPS) Directorate.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Most organisms, even microscopic ones, have a sense of touch ? they can detect a poke or pull or the movement of water across their surface. Inspired by discussions at the NSF-sponsored Square Table-2 meeting about how the development of materials might be advanced by incorporating ideas from synthetic biology, we asked whether there might be a simple way to impart soft materials such as bandages or gels with the ability to react to forces on them by imitating some of what is known about how cells use molecules to sense and then react to force.

We focused our attention on understanding how to build hydrogels with an ability to react to forces by peeling from a surface. Hydrogels are materials similar in properties to living tissues, and are important for in many areas of biotechnology such as creating hydrogel bandages. We asked whether there might be a means to allow a hydrogel change shape in response to light touch as a means of delicate removal from a surface.

To achieve this objective, we studied how well-understood biomolecules, DNA, embedded in a standard hydrogel often used for bandages and other devices, a polyethylene glycol hydrogel, reacted to different kinds of forces (or stress).  We used multimode force microscopy, a technique developed by the Frechette lab, to precisely measure the responses of the gels and the DNA inside to different forces. These results demonstrated how a predictable chemical reaction of the DNA with another substrate could be induced, at a specific rate, when a specific stress was applied.  One result of these studies was that we observed that our approach could response even to the light touch one might apply to a cell phone. Using methods from synthetic biology, we designed a cascade of biochemical reactions involving short DNA molecules and enzymes that caused the hydrogel to change shape when enough force was applied.  Our more general material studies helped us also understand how the same approach could be applied predictably to different types of hydrogels and how we might cause different kinds of responses by combining molecules that trigger different responses as a result of stress and to response to different amounts or patterns of stress that are applied.  This work provides a new approach for building biocompatible materials that respond intelligently and also demonstrates how combining ideas from materials science and synthetic biology can address challenging problems in human health and society.

This project further provided multi-disciplinary training for 4 graduate students and 4 undergraduate students.  Material from this work was included in courses in chemical and biomolecular engineering and mechanical engineering at Johns Hopkins. It also supported outreach and collaboration with an artist in residence from the Maryland Institute College of Art, who produced woven art pieces using the inspiration of synthetic biology.  Finally, this project supported the professional development of diverse PhD students for careers in industry through the Passport to Future Technology Leadership program at Johns Hopkins.
